Dear Ms. Ketchum:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
January 10, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please
contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include

documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
One of four new employee files had documentation completed but it was not
within the 30-day period.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Consultant spoke with administration to make sure that report dates for youth
are not starting the same date as the last report date ended.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The chief administrator assessment report was reviewed and found to be
written on the wrong form. All the needed information was on the form and the
correct form was provided to the facility for future chief administrator
assessment reports.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the
provisional licensing period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
review period begins August 14, 2023, until current. The agency was granted a 1st
Provisional License on August 14, 2023. The facility had three special
investigations during the period under review with two resulting in a corrective
action plan (CAP) and one that remains pending. The special investigations
resulting in non-compliance was for the not having a policy for appropriate video
game usage with the youth and staff not following the facility's behavior

management policy as staff did not use appropriate language around the youth.
Monthly unannounced visits to the facility have been completed and
implementation of their corrective action plan has been noted.
The agency was placed on a 1st provisional license as a result of special
investigation 20223C0000500. The agency was successful in implementing the
corrective action plan that was approved from that investigation and the six other
corrective action plans that were active during the 1st provisional license. Staff that
were involved in inappropriate restraint techniques and interventions standards
have all been terminated and not eligible for rehire. Since going onto a 1st
provisional license the facility has made significant progress and improvements
into the programs and safety of the youth. The facility has restructured and rehired
their team. A team lead position has been implemented into the program that is not
counted within ratio, to help support staff in ratio. The facility has hired a new chief
administrator and therapist to help support the growth. The facility continues to
meet the staff to youth ratio requirements and had a person in leadership working
outside of the ratio to help support. The training model has been updated to
include more frequent and robust training on restraint model, behavior
management, trauma informed care, and mandated reporting. Policies and
procedures have been developed and approved by DCWL that include behavior
management, supervision guidelines, and mandated reporting. All corrective action
plans have been implemented and all action steps have been met in the required
timeframes.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator reported since the start of the 1st provisional license there was
many major positive impacts created by corrective action plan compliance. Chief
Administrator reported, "Having Genacross leadership more present was impactful
and helped us gain improved knowledge of the abilities and needs of staff at
Adrian. The hiring of a more experienced shift manager and a new Chief
Administrator has improved the confidence and the knowledge base at Adrian as
well." The facility plans to continue with their additional trainings related to
managing difficult youth, trauma focused training, approved restraint model
techniques, and de-escalation techniques so staff can gain knowledge and skills in
making the right decisions in times of crisis and conflict with the youth. The
facilities goal for the next year is to continue to focus on prevention strategies and
ways to decrease the use of restraints at the facility.

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff have reported they feel very supported by leadership and have appreciated
having the extra lead role out of ratio to help support in crisis situations. One of
the staff members interviewed worked at the facility prior to the 1st provisional and
reported seeing positive improvements in training and support. The staff reported
they feel things are communicated well and if there are changes to policies or
procedures or safety plans of youth, they receive the information in a timely and
clear manner.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. The youth reported they feel safe and have a positive relationship
with the staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on January 10, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
